title: Ruth and Boaz
shortSummary: In Ruth chapter 3, Naomi instructs Ruth to seek security through Boaz, their kinsman-redeemer, by approaching him at the threshing floor. Ruth’s bold and respectful actions lead to Boaz’s promise to fulfill his duty if the nearer kinsman declines, highlighting God’s providential care and the unfolding redemption plan.
timeline: c. 1200 BC - Period of the Judges

keyCharacters.name: Ruth
keyCharacters.description: A Moabite widow who shows loyalty to Naomi and courageously seeks Boaz’s protection as her kinsman-redeemer.

keyCharacters.name: Naomi
keyCharacters.description: Ruth’s mother-in-law who advises and guides Ruth in the cultural practice of seeking a kinsman-redeemer.

keyCharacters.name: Boaz
keyCharacters.description: A wealthy and honorable relative of Naomi’s family who acts as the potential kinsman-redeemer for Ruth.

definitions.definition: A close relative who has the responsibility to redeem or buy back a relative in need, preserving family inheritance and providing protection.
A flat surface where grain is separated from chaff, often a place of work and social interaction in ancient Israel.
A Hebrew idiom meaning to extend protection or take responsibility for someone, symbolizing marriage or guardianship.
To apply oil ceremonially, often signifying preparation, consecration, or honor.

outline.heading: Naomi’s Plan for Ruth’s Security
outline.description: Naomi encourages Ruth to seek rest and security by approaching Boaz, giving detailed instructions on how to respectfully present herself to him at the threshing floor.

outline.heading: Ruth’s Bold Approach to Boaz
outline.description: Ruth follows Naomi’s instructions, quietly approaching Boaz at night, uncovering his feet, and requesting his protection as her kinsman-redeemer.

outline.heading: Boaz’s Blessing and Promise
outline.description: Boaz praises Ruth’s kindness and virtue, acknowledges the presence of a nearer kinsman, and promises to act on her behalf if the closer relative refuses.

outline.heading: Ruth’s Departure and Naomi’s Hope
outline.description: Ruth stays until morning, receives a gift of barley from Boaz, and returns to Naomi, who encourages patience as the matter is resolved.

application: Trust God’s providence by taking wise and courageous steps in seeking His provision and protection.
Obey godly counsel from mature believers, recognizing the value of wisdom in navigating difficult situations.
Demonstrate integrity and humility in relationships, honoring God through respectful and honorable actions.
Be patient and trust God’s timing when awaiting the fulfillment of His promises.

keyVerses.text: And he said, Who art thou? And she answered, I am Ruth thine handmaid: spread therefore thy skirt over thine handmaid; for thou art a near kinsman.
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures Ruth’s humble yet bold request for Boaz’s protection, symbolizing her appeal for redemption and God’s provision.

keyVerses.text: And now, my daughter, fear not; I will do to thee all that thou requirest: for all the city of my people doth know that thou art a virtuous woman.
keyVerses.significance: Boaz’s assurance highlights the importance of character and reputation, and his commitment to act honorably on Ruth’s behalf.

keyVerses.text: Tarry this night, and it shall be in the morning, that if he will perform unto thee the part of a kinsman, well; let him do the kinsman's part: but if he will not do the part of a kinsman to thee, then will I do the part of a kinsman to thee, as the LORD liveth: lie down until the morning.
keyVerses.significance: Boaz’s promise demonstrates faithful commitment and trust in God’s sovereign plan for redemption.
